longest_values: Specialized High Schools Diversity Initiative - Leverage existing middle school after school programs to implement new Specialized High School Admissions Test preparation programs
Specialized High Schools Diversity Initiative -  Improve school climate at the Specialized High Schools to create more welcoming school cultures for diverse learners
Specialized High Schools Diversity Initiative - Expand DREAM, a SHSAT preparation program, to serve additional rising 8th grade students in an Intensive program

frequent_values: Through Algebra for All, by 2022, every student will have access to Algebra in 8th grade, complete Algebra no later than 9th grade, and there will be academic supports in place in elementary and middle school to build greater Algebra readiness. As of fall 2017, approximately 900 teachers across 357 elementary, middle, and high schools have received Algebra for All training to strengthen math instruction and are working to increase the amount of time they devote to math instruction. 139 elementary schools are working to “departmentalize” 5th-grade math – having their math instruction led by a specialized teacher who has received intensive training.

The DOE has committed to making sure every school building has a single stall bathroom available to support the privacy needs of students, including those with medical conditions and disabilities, as well as transgender and gender non-conforming students. Schools are supported with making sure the lock is accessible and signage is consistent across all schools. The DOE began implementation of this in the 2016-17 school year and will continue until all schools have a single stall bathroom.

All middle and high schools that participate in the DOE's centralized admissions process have seats allocated for Students with Disabilities (SWDs). This enrollment target is set in proportion to the overall percent of SWDs by borough (for High School) and by district (for Middle School). In the annual school directories, the DOE continued to provide information about seat availability and prior-year demand for each program for General Education and SWDs separately in order to highlight the fact that all schools serve SWDs.
In 2016-17, families continued to have the opportunity to select testing sites that met their accessibility needs.

shortest_values: The DOE targets families who did not apply through admissions using both English and Spanish.
In 2016-17, families continued to have the opportunity to select testing sites that met their accessibility needs.
To give families the maximum amount of time in which to apply, the DOE opened the Round 2 application three weeks ahead of schedule and did not change the planned close date.
The DOE continued to support middle schools in recruiting and supporting students with disabilities, including middle schools that currently serve lower numbers of students with disabilities.
The DOE is partnering with WXY Studio, a public engagement firm, and Community School District 15 to implement a public engagement process to foster school diversity in Community School District 15.
longest_values: Through the Expanded Success Initiative (ESI), the DOE facilitated monthly open forums with school leaders, students, and community members to unpack issues related to race, gender and class. It also hosted a peer-to-peer mentorship program, serving primarily young men of color, aimed at engaging students from underserved communities in a college and career readiness mindset. Additionally, in partnership with the Center for Strategic Solutions at NYU, ESI hosted a Critically Conscious Educators Rising (CCER) Series that convened a group of like-minded educators to focus on tying theory to practice in the pursuit of equity and racial justice in their classrooms, through their peers, and beyond. Through the ESI Leadership Institute, the DOE hosted a four-part collaborative series bringing together principals and assistant principals to explore systematic bias and racism in schools and what building leaders can do to disrupt it. Administrators and leaders from over 30 schools have come together to learn how to create a roadmap towards an equity-driven school community using data and guided by a root cause analysis process.

As part of Progressive Redesign Opportunity Schools for Excellence (PROSE), schools are allowed flexibility in how their school day is organized and encouraged to implement models of teacher inter-visitation, with many schools centering this work on the goal of meeting the needs of a diverse student body. In 2016-17, 79 schools participated in schedule flexibility, allowing leaders to tailor school structure to meet specific needs of school communities. Many schools have implemented teacher inter-visitations, encouraging the sharing of best practices in how to most effectively serve a diverse school community. Last year’s survey results show that of the schools surveyed, 76% feel that the scheduling flexibility created more opportunities for teachers to collaborate. Other benefits include: increased instructional time for students, additional time for parent engagement, and more opportunities for student advisory support.

Supports and interventions have been put into place to increase awareness of and access to 3K through High School admissions processes for students in temporary housing and their families. These interventions have included transportation provided to admissions events, admissions hubs for students at fairs, trainings for shelter staff, shelter-based workshops, direct outreach to pre-Kindergarten non-applicants and other opportunities for targeted admissions support. In the 2016-17 admissions cycle, 41 percent of eligible students in shelter applied for Kindergarten, up from 36 the previous year. 32 percent of 8th graders in shelter listed 12 choices on their high school application – up from 27 percent the previous year, and higher than the citywide average. In 2017-18, the DOE will expand the number of admissions hubs and offer targeted shelter-based events.

In 2016-17, the DOE formed a team of outreach specialists focused on raising awareness about the Specialized High Schools (SHS). The team called thousands of families, attended more than 20 events, and presented about the SHS at ~25 middle schools in underrepresented districts (Districts 4-6 in Manhattan, Districts 7-12 in the Bronx, and Districts 16-19, 23 and 32 in Brooklyn).  In spring 2017, the DOE hosted inaugural SHS fairs in Brooklyn and the Bronx with the goal of increasing awareness about the SHS in communities that are underrepresented at the schools. ~5,000 people attended across both events. In 2017-18, the outreach team will continue to build upon this work by strengthening relationships with community partners with the goal of effectively promoting and increasing visibility of the SHS to students and families from underrepresented backgrounds.

The Progressive Redesign Opportunity Schools for Excellence (PROSE) used funding from the National Education Association to provide $750 mini-grants and an opportunity to apply for up to $5,000 in mini-grant funding to 10 schools who sought to increase diversity in their school communities. Many of these schools utilized this funding to provide planning time for school staff working on diversity issues, as well as to do additional recruitment and outreach to underrepresented populations through school fairs and direct communication to families. Additionally, schools also utilized this funding to better equip their schools to support diverse learners. Examples of these activities included full-day professional development and guest speakers. Of the 155 schools in the program, 10 schools received grants of up to $5,000 for this effort.
